content:
@WG-prioritization/alerts issue #85241 has been requested for prioritization.

Procedure

  • Priority?
  • Regression?
  • Notify people/groups?
  • Needs I-nominated?
P-medium or P-high - I kind of lean towards P-medium since this only occurs on invalid code

ok for P-medium though I wonder how misleading the original error is (I see the segfault but no clear indication on where to look). How the issue reporter managed to connect the TypeFoldable::fold_with to the correct codepoint
sometimes we assigned a P-high on really misleading errors because they are maddening :-)
hmm, I feel like we've been assigning a lot of P-high's lately
I think we should be careful to distinguish "we really want to fix this" from "this has a large impact"
if there's a really bad diagnostic that only affects 5 people in the world, there's no reason for it to be P-high

apiraino: ok for P-medium though I wonder how misleading the original error is (I see the segfault but no clear indication on where to look). How the issue reporter managed to connect the TypeFoldable::fold_with to the correct codepoint

they used GDB to get a backtrace of the segfault

Joshua Nelson said:

hmm, I feel like we've been assigning a lot of P-high's lately

in particular, if everything is P-high then they don't actually get solved any faster; I've noticed a lot of them piling up recently

I agree with your general point, though often one person == one issue (and only sometimes we have more people filing the same issue and we close them as dupes). The "horizontal" impact of an issue is relevant (= how many ppl) so if this code is not general enough ok for a p-medium

Though I also think (in a very handwavy way) that if we have many P-high lately (maybe due to some heavyweight stuff recently merged) we should also look at why p-high issues are not closed fast enough (for any value of "fast") and why they are not caught before - rather than deprioritising them
